<|ref|>title<|/ref|><|det|>[[97, 118, 379, 144]]<|/det|>
# Cambridge IGCSE™  

<|ref|>sub_title<|/ref|><|det|>[[97, 170, 183, 187]]<|/det|>
## PHYSICS  

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[97, 193, 368, 210]]<|/det|>
Paper 2 Multiple Choice (Extended)  

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[782, 170, 905, 187]]<|/det|>
0625/21  

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[782, 194, 905, 210]]<|/det|>
May/June 2023  

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[814, 216, 905, 231]]<|/det|>
45 minutes  

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[97, 246, 507, 263]]<|/det|>
You must answer on the multiple choice answer sheet.  

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[97, 277, 437, 293]]<|/det|>
You will need: Multiple choice answer sheet  

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[215, 291, 539, 320]]<|/det|>
Soft clean eraser Soft pencil (type B or HB is recommended)  

<|ref|>sub_title<|/ref|><|det|>[[97, 337, 228, 352]]<|/det|>
## INSTRUCTIONS  

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[97, 353, 115, 368]]<|/det|>
<label>OR</label>

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[129, 352, 599, 369]]<|/det|>
There are forty questions on this paper. Answer all questions.  

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[97, 368, 907, 400]]<|/det|>
For each question there are four possible answers A, B, C and D. Choose the one you consider correct and record your choice in soft pencil on the multiple choice answer sheet.  

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[97, 399, 579, 415]]<|/det|>
Follow the instructions on the multiple choice answer sheet.  

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[97, 415, 277, 430]]<|/det|>
Write in soft pencil.  

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[97, 430, 868, 461]]<|/det|>
Write your name, centre number and candidate number on the multiple choice answer sheet in the spaces provided unless this has been done for you.  

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[97, 460, 327, 475]]<|/det|>
Do not use correction fluid.  

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[97, 476, 364, 491]]<|/det|>
Do not write on any bar codes.  

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[97, 491, 329, 506]]<|/det|>
You may use a calculator.  

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[97, 507, 680, 523]]<|/det|>
Take the weight of \(1.0\mathrm{kg}\) to be \(9.8\mathrm{N}\) (acceleration of free fall \(= 9.8\mathrm{m / s}^2\) ).  

<|ref|>sub_title<|/ref|><|det|>[[97, 549, 220, 564]]<|/det|>

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[97, 565, 570, 615]]<|/det|>
The total mark for this paper is 40. Each correct answer will score one mark. Any rough working should be done on this question paper.

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[79, 72, 107, 89]]<|/det|>
<label>15</label>

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[116, 72, 596, 89]]<|/det|>

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[186, 101, 210, 119]]<|/det|>
<label>1</label>

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[222, 101, 620, 120]]<|/det|>

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[185, 128, 205, 146]]<|/det|>
<label>2</label>

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[222, 127, 920, 161]]<|/det|>

<label>3</label>

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[222, 168, 527, 186]]<|/det|>

2

by conduction then convection

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[112, 345, 134, 364]]<|/det|>
<label>B</label>

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[148, 345, 386, 363]]<|/det|>

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[112, 371, 133, 389]]<|/det|>

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[148, 371, 411, 388]]<|/det|>

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[112, 131, 134, 147]]<|/det|> <|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[149, 129, 920, 163]]<|/det|> The resistance of the wire is directly proportional to its cross-sectional area and inversely proportional to its diameter. <|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[112, 172, 133, 190]]<|/det|> <|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[149, 170, 920, 203]]<|/det|> The resistance of the wire is directly proportional to its cross-sectional area and inversely proportional to its length. <|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[112, 212, 133, 230]]<|/det|> <|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[149, 211, 920, 243]]<|/det|> The resistance of the wire is directly proportional to its length and inversely proportional to its cross-sectional area. <|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[112, 252, 133, 270]]<|/det|> <|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[149, 252, 920, 284]]<|/det|> The resistance of the wire is directly proportional to its length and inversely proportional to its diameter. <|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[77, 312, 106, 330]]<|/det|> <|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[114, 312, 635, 330]]<|/det|> The diagram shows the current–voltage graph for a metal wire. <|ref|>image<|/ref|><|det|>[[379, 341, 616, 476]]<|/det|> <|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[112, 490, 437, 507]]<|/det|> What can be deduced from the graph? <|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[114, 71, 920, 106]]<|/det|>
The circuit diagram shows two identical lamps connected in parallel to a cell. Three ammeters, X, Y and Z, are also connected in the circuit, as shown.

<label>A</label>

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[148, 312, 576, 331]]<|/det|>
It is equal to the current in Y and to the current in Z.

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[112, 339, 134, 357]]<|/det|>
<label>B</label>

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[148, 339, 601, 357]]<|/det|>

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[112, 364, 131, 383]]<|/det|>
<label>C</label>

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[148, 364, 648, 383]]<|/det|>
It is equal to the sum of the current in Y and the current in Z.

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[112, 390, 133, 409]]<|/det|>
<label>D</label>

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[148, 390, 751, 408]]<|/det|>
It is equal to the difference between the current in Y and the current in Z.

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[112, 356, 134, 375]]<|/det|> <|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[149, 356, 263, 375]]<|/det|> into the page <|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[112, 383, 134, 401]]<|/det|> <|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[149, 383, 280, 401]]<|/det|> out of the page <|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[112, 409, 134, 428]]<|/det|> <|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[149, 409, 411, 427]]<|/det|> towards the bottom of the page <|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[112, 435, 134, 454]]<|/det|> <|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[149, 435, 381, 453]]<|/det|> towards the top of the page <|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[77, 479, 106, 497]]<|/det|> <|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[114, 479, 514, 497]]<|/det|> Which statement about a transformer is correct? <|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[112, 507, 133, 526]]<|/det|> <|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[149, 507, 883, 526]]<|/det|> There is an alternating current in the iron core from the primary coil to the secondary coil. <|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[112, 534, 133, 553]]<|/det|> <|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[149, 534, 888, 552]]<|/det|> An alternating current in the iron core induces an alternating current in the secondary coil. <|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[112, 560, 131, 579]]<|/det|> <|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[149, 560, 860, 577]]<|/det|> An alternating current in the primary coil induces a direct current in the secondary coil. <|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[112, 586, 131, 604]]<|/det|> <|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[149, 586, 920, 619]]<|/det|> An alternating current in the primary coil induces an alternating voltage across the secondary coil. <|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[77, 644, 106, 663]]<|/det|> <|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[114, 644, 579, 663]]<|/det|> How are positive and negative ions formed from atoms? <|ref|>table<|/ref|><|det|>[[114, 673, 897, 804]]<|/det|>
positive ionnegative ion
Aadd positive charge to the nucleusadd an electron to the atom
Badd positive charge to the nucleusremove positive charge from the nucleus
Cremove an electron from the atomadd an electron to the atom
Dremove an electron from the atomremove positive charge from the nucleus

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[77, 72, 106, 88]]<|/det|>
<label>39</label>

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[114, 72, 490, 89]]<|/det|>
Which nuclear reaction powers a stable star?

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[112, 100, 133, 117]]<|/det|>
<label>A</label>

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[149, 100, 517, 118]]<|/det|>
nuclear fission of nuclei producing hydrogen

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[112, 125, 133, 144]]<|/det|>
<label>B</label>

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[149, 125, 819, 144]]<|/det|>
nuclear fission of a uranium nucleus into a krypton nucleus and a barium nucleus

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[112, 152, 133, 170]]<|/det|>
<label>C</label>

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[149, 151, 816, 170]]<|/det|>
nuclear fusion of a krypton nucleus and a barium nucleus into a uranium nucleus

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[112, 178, 133, 196]]<|/det|>
<label>D</label>

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[149, 178, 574, 196]]<|/det|>
nuclear fusion of hydrogen nuclei producing helium

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[77, 222, 106, 241]]<|/det|>
<label>40</label>

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[114, 222, 747, 241]]<|/det|>
Which stages in the life cycle of a star are listed in the order that they occur?

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[112, 252, 133, 269]]<|/det|>
<label>A</label>

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[149, 252, 547, 269]]<|/det|>
interstellar dust cloud \(\rightarrow\) stable star \(\rightarrow\) protostar

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[112, 280, 133, 297]]<|/det|>
<label>B</label>

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[149, 280, 445, 297]]<|/det|>
protostar \(\rightarrow\) red giant \(\rightarrow\) stable star

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[112, 307, 133, 325]]<|/det|>
<label>C</label>

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[149, 307, 450, 325]]<|/det|>
red giant \(\rightarrow\) white dwarf \(\rightarrow\) protostar

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[112, 335, 133, 352]]<|/det|>
<label>D</label>

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[151, 335, 465, 352]]<|/det|>
stable star \(\rightarrow\) red giant \(\rightarrow\) white dwarf

To avoid the issue of disclosure of answer- related information to candidates, all copyright acknowledgements are reproduced online in the Cambridge Assessment International Education Copyright Acknowledgements Booklet. This is produced for each series of examinations and is freely available to download at www.cambridgeinternational.org after the live examination series.  

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[80, 916, 920, 939]]<|/det|>
Cambridge Assessment International Education is part of Cambridge Assessment. Cambridge Assessment is the brand name of the University of Cambridge Local Examinations Syndicate (UCLES), which is a department of the University of Cambridge.
